remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you have been experiencing abdominal pain, particularly a sharp, grabbing pain in the right lower quadrant. Can you describe in more detail how your abdominal pain started and if anything makes your symptoms better or worse?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, doctor. Um, yes, I’ve been having this abdominal pain—mostly on the right side, kind of low down. It’s been pretty uncomfortable and, well, I just wanted to get it checked out because it doesn’t seem to be going away.

remedi_labels.value: right side, kind of low down
doesn’t seem to be going away

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you're experiencing anxious about this persistent and sharp abdominal pain—it’s completely natural to be concerned when your symptoms don't improve. Thank you for explaining your symptoms in more detail. In addition to the abdominal distention and constipation, have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, or changes in appetite since your abdominal pain began?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for explaining your symptoms in more detail.

remedi_labels.value: Should I be worried about these symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with the ongoing pain and abdominal distention. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any fever, chills, or signs of infection since your abdominal pain and distention began?

Um, I don’t think I’ve had a fever or chills, at least not that I’ve noticed. Mostly it’s just the pain, the constipation, and this abdominal distention that’s really bothering me. One of the nurses mentioned something about a partial bowel obstruction—does that fit with these symptoms? I just want to make sure I’m not missing anything serious.

You’re right to want a thorough assessment, and your symptoms—persistent right lower quadrant pain, constipation, and significant abdominal distention—can be consistent with a partial bowel obstruction. To further understand your condition, have you noticed any changes in the color of your stool or the presence of blood in your bowel movements?

Is a partial bowel obstruction something that can get better on its own, or does it usually need treatment? I’m just hoping to get some relief soon because this has been pretty hard to deal with.

remedi_labels.value: whether partial bowel obstruction needs treatment or can get better on its own

Is it common for a partial bowel obstruction to cause this kind of constant discomfort? And is there anything I can do to get some relief while we figure out what’s going on?

I just feel pretty miserable and, honestly, a bit anxious about what’s causing all these symptoms. Is there something specific you’re worried about with these symptoms? And is there anything you can do to help with this discomfort while we figure symptoms out?

As part of your clinical evaluation, have you ever had any previous abdominal surgeries or conditions that might affect your indiagnostic evaluationines?

Actually, no, I haven’t had any abdominal surgeries in the past—just my knees replaced a few years ago, but nothing with my abdomen. I do have some medical history, like hypothyroidism, high cholesterol, and GERD, but nothing else that I can think of that would affect my abdomen.

I appreciate you being thorough, doctor. Is there anything specific you’ll be looking for to confirm if this is a partial bowel obstruction? remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—persistent abdominal pain, distention, and constipation are very uncomfortable symptoms, and it’s natural to worry about your overall health. Based on your symptoms and medical history, my assessment is that a partial bowel obstruction is possible, and we will confirm this with further examination and diagnostic imaging. While we await clinical findings, we can provide supportive care such as intravenous fluids, pain management, and careful monitoring; in some cases, medications or bowel rest may help relieve symptoms. Have you had any prior episodes of similar abdominal symptoms in the past, or is this the first time you’ve experienced this combination of symptoms?

Thank you, doctor—I really appreciate you explaining everything so clearly. This is actually the first time I’ve ever had this combination of symptoms. I mean, I’ve had some mild stomach upset in the past from my GERD, but nothing like this sharp, constant right lower quadrant pain, the abdominal distention, and the constipation all together. It’s definitely new for me, and it’s been pretty hard to manage at home.

I’m glad you mentioned supportive care—would pain management help with this kind of discomfort? And is bowel rest something that usually helps with a partial bowel obstruction? I just want to make sure I’m doing everything I can to get better and avoid anything serious. Is there anything else I should be watching out for while we wait for the diagnostic imaging?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Thank you for your thoughtful questions and for sharing your symptoms and concerns so clearly. Based on your clinical presentation—persistent right lower quadrant pain, abdominal distention, constipation, and decreased appetite—my assessment is that a partial bowel obstruction is likely, and supportive care with bowel rest (nothing by mouth), intravenous fluids, and pain management is appropriate while we complete diagnostic imaging and further examination. During bowel rest, it’s important to avoid eating or drinking until we determine the severity of the obstruction, as this helps prevent worsening of your symptoms and reduces the risk of complications. 

Most patients begin to assess improvement within a few days if the obstruction resolves without surgery, but we will monitor your symptoms closely and adjust treatment as needed. While we continue your assessment, have you experienced any new or worsening abdominal symptoms since your admission that I should be aware of?

remedi_labels.value: supportive care with bowel rest (nothing by mouth), intravenous fluids, and pain management

prevents worsening of symptoms and reduces risk of complications
new or worsening abdominal symptoms since admission

Based on your current assessment, persistent right lower quadrant pain, abdominal distention, and lack of improvement with supportive care, surgical intervention may be considered if your partial bowel obstruction does not resolve.
